# Winter Olympic Games

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For a list of Winter Olympic Games, see the list below.

"Winter Olympics" redirects here. For the TV episode of the The Goodies, see
[Winter Olympics (The Goodies)](/wiki/Winter_Olympics_\(The_Goodies\) "Winter
Olympics \(The Goodies\)"). For the video game, see [Winter Olympics (video
game)](/wiki/Winter_Olympics_\(video_game\) "Winter Olympics \(video game\)").

The **Winter Olympic Games** (French: _Jeux olympiques d 'hiver_)[nb 1] is a
major international sporting event held once every four years for sports
practised on snow and ice. The first Winter Olympics, the [1924 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics "1924 Winter Olympics"), were held in
[Chamonix](/wiki/Chamonix "Chamonix"), France. The modern Olympic games were
inspired by the ancient Olympic Games, which were held in Olympia, Greece,
from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD. [Baron Pierre de
Coubertin](/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin "Pierre de Coubertin") founded the
[International Olympic Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee
"International Olympic Committee") (IOC) in 1894, leading to the first modern
Summer Games in Athens, Greece in 1896. The IOC is the governing body of the
Olympic Movement, with the Olympic Charter defining its structure and
authority.

The original five Winter Olympics sports (broken into nine disciplines) were
[bobsleigh](/wiki/Bobsleigh_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Bobsleigh at the 1924
Winter Olympics"), [curling](/wiki/Curling_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics
"Curling at the 1924 Winter Olympics"), [ice
hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey at the 1924
Winter Olympics"), [Nordic
skiing](/wiki/Nordic_skiing_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Nordic skiing at the
1924 Winter Olympics") (consisting of the disciplines [military
patrol](/wiki/Military_patrol_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Military patrol at
the 1924 Winter Olympics"),[nb 2] [cross-country skiing](/wiki/Cross-
country_skiing_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Cross-country skiing at the 1924
Winter Olympics"), [Nordic
combined](/wiki/Nordic_combined_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Nordic combined
at the 1924 Winter Olympics"), and [ski
jumping](/wiki/Ski_jumping_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Ski jumping at the
1924 Winter Olympics")), and [skating](/wiki/Ice_Skating "Ice Skating")
(consisting of the disciplines [figure
skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Figure skating at
the 1924 Winter Olympics") and [speed
skating](/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Speed skating at the
1924 Winter Olympics")).[nb 3] The Games were held every four years from 1924
to 1936, interrupted in 1940 and 1944 by [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II"), and resumed in [1948](/wiki/1948_Winter_Olympics "1948 Winter
Olympics"). Until [1992](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter Olympics")
the Winter and [Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer
Olympic Games") were held in the same years, but in accordance with a 1986
decision by the [IOC](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International
Olympic Committee") to place the Summer and Winter Games on separate four-year
cycles in alternating even-numbered years, the next Winter Olympics after 1992
was in [1994](/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics "1994 Winter Olympics").

The Winter Games have evolved since their inception. Sports and disciplines
have been added and some of them, such as [Alpine
skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Alpine skiing at the
Winter Olympics"), [luge](/wiki/Luge_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Luge at the
Winter Olympics"), [short track speed
skating](/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Short track
speed skating at the Winter Olympics"), [freestyle
skiing](/wiki/Freestyle_skiing_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Freestyle skiing at the
Winter Olympics"), [skeleton](/wiki/Skeleton_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Skeleton
at the Winter Olympics"), and
[snowboarding](/wiki/Snowboarding_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Snowboarding at the
Winter Olympics"), have earned a permanent spot on the Olympic programme. Some
others, including [curling](/wiki/Curling_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Curling at
the Winter Olympics") and [bobsleigh](/wiki/Bobsleigh_at_the_Winter_Olympics
"Bobsleigh at the Winter Olympics"), have been discontinued and later
reintroduced; others have been permanently discontinued, such as [military
patrol](/wiki/Military_patrol_\(sport\) "Military patrol \(sport\)"), though
the modern Winter Olympic sport of
[biathlon](/wiki/Biathlon_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Biathlon at the Winter
Olympics") is descended from it.[nb 2] Still others, such as [speed
skiing](/wiki/Speed_skiing "Speed skiing"), [bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy") and
[skijoring](/wiki/Skijoring "Skijoring"), were [demonstration
sports](/wiki/Demonstration_sports "Demonstration sports") but never
incorporated as Olympic sports. The rise of television as a global medium for
communication enhanced the profile of the Games. It generated income via the
sale of broadcast rights and advertising, which has become lucrative for the
IOC. This allowed outside interests, such as television companies and
corporate sponsors, to exert influence. The IOC has had to address numerous
criticisms over the decades like internal scandals, the use of [performance-
enhancing drugs](/wiki/Doping_at_the_Olympic_Games "Doping at the Olympic
Games") by Winter Olympians, as well as a political [boycott](/wiki/Boycott
"Boycott") of the Winter Olympics. Nations have used the Winter (as well as
Summer) Games to proclaim the superiority of their political systems.

The Winter Olympics has been hosted on three continents by twelve different
countries. The Games have been held four times in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_at_the_Olympics "United States at the Olympics")
(in [1932](/wiki/1932_Winter_Olympics "1932 Winter Olympics"),
[1960](/wiki/1960_Winter_Olympics "1960 Winter Olympics"),
[1980](/wiki/1980_Winter_Olympics "1980 Winter Olympics") and
[2002](/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics "2002 Winter Olympics")); three times in
[France](/wiki/France_at_the_Olympics "France at the Olympics") (in
[1924](/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics "1924 Winter Olympics"),
[1968](/wiki/1968_Winter_Olympics "1968 Winter Olympics") and
[1992](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter Olympics")); and twice each in
[Austria](/wiki/Austria_at_the_Olympics "Austria at the Olympics")
([1964](/wiki/1964_Winter_Olympics "1964 Winter Olympics"),
[1976](/wiki/1976_Winter_Olympics "1976 Winter Olympics")),
[Canada](/wiki/Canada_at_the_Olympics "Canada at the Olympics")
([1988](/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics "1988 Winter Olympics"),
[2010](/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics "2010 Winter Olympics")),
[Japan](/wiki/Japan_at_the_Olympics "Japan at the Olympics")
([1972](/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics "1972 Winter Olympics"),
[1998](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter Olympics")),
[Italy](/wiki/Italy_at_the_Olympics "Italy at the Olympics")
([1956](/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics "1956 Winter Olympics"),
[2006](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics")),
[Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_Olympics "Norway at the Olympics")
([1952](/wiki/1952_Winter_Olympics "1952 Winter Olympics"),
[1994](/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics "1994 Winter Olympics")), and
[Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland_at_the_Olympics "Switzerland at the Olympics")
([1928](/wiki/1928_Winter_Olympics "1928 Winter Olympics"),
[1948](/wiki/1948_Winter_Olympics "1948 Winter Olympics")). Also, the Games
have been held just once each in [Germany](/wiki/Germany_at_the_Olympics
"Germany at the Olympics") [(1936)](/wiki/1936_Winter_Olympics "1936 Winter
Olympics"), [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia_at_the_Olympics "Yugoslavia at the
Olympics") ([1984](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics")),
[Russia](/wiki/Russia_at_the_Olympics "Russia at the Olympics")
([2014](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics")) and [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_at_the_Olympics "South Korea at the Olympics")
([2018](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics "2018 Winter Olympics")). The IOC has
selected [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), [China](/wiki/China "China"), to
host the [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022 Winter
Olympics") and the host of the [2026 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/2026_Winter_Olympics "2026 Winter Olympics") will be selected
in September 2019. As of
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Winter_Olympic_Games&action=edit),
no city in the [southern hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_hemisphere "Southern
hemisphere") has applied to host the cold-weather-dependent Winter Olympics,
which are held in February at the height of the southern hemisphere summer.

To date, twelve countries have participated in every Winter Olympic Games –
Austria, Canada, [Finland](/wiki/Finland_at_the_Olympics "Finland at the
Olympics"), France, [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics "Great
Britain at the Olympics"), [Hungary](/wiki/Hungary_at_the_Olympics "Hungary at
the Olympics"), Italy, Norway, [Poland](/wiki/Poland_at_the_Olympics "Poland
at the Olympics"), [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_at_the_Olympics "Sweden at the
Olympics"), Switzerland and the United States. Six of those countries have
earned medals at every Winter Olympic Games – Austria, Canada, Finland,
Norway, Sweden and the United States. The only country to have earned a gold
medal at every Winter Olympics is the United States. Norway leads the [all-
time medal table](/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table#Winter_Olympics
"All-time Olympic Games medal table") for the Winter Olympics both on number
of gold and overall medals, followed by the United States and Germany.

## History

### 20th century

#### 1900 to 1912

[![a man standing on ice in figure
skates](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/1908_Olympic_Games_Ulrich_Salchow.jpg/170px-1908_Olympic_Games_Ulrich_Salchow.jpg)](/wiki/File:1908_Olympic_Games_Ulrich_Salchow.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1908_Olympic_Games_Ulrich_Salchow.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ulrich Salchow](/wiki/Ulrich_Salchow "Ulrich Salchow")  
at the 1908 Olympics.

A predecessor, the [Nordic Games](/wiki/Nordic_Games "Nordic Games"), were
organised by General [Viktor Gustaf Balck](/wiki/Viktor_Gustaf_Balck "Viktor
Gustaf Balck") in [Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), Sweden in 1901 and
were held again in 1903 and 1905 and then every fourth year thereafter until
1926.[5] Balck was a charter member of the
[IOC](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic Committee")
and a close friend of [Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games")
founder [Pierre de Coubertin](/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin "Pierre de
Coubertin"). He attempted to have winter sports, specifically [figure
skating](/wiki/Figure_skating "Figure skating"), added to the Olympic
programme but was unsuccessful until the [1908 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics "1908 Summer Olympics") in
[London](/wiki/London "London"), United Kingdom.[5] Four figure skating events
were contested, at which [Ulrich Salchow](/wiki/Ulrich_Salchow "Ulrich
Salchow") (10-time world champion) and [Madge Syers](/wiki/Madge_Syers "Madge
Syers") won the individual titles.[6][7]

Three years later, Italian count [Eugenio Brunetta
d'Usseaux](/wiki/Eugenio_Brunetta_d%27Usseaux "Eugenio Brunetta d'Usseaux")
proposed that the IOC stage a week of winter sports included as part of the
[1912 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1912_Summer_Olympics "1912 Summer Olympics") in
[Stockholm](/wiki/Stockholm "Stockholm"), Sweden. The organisers opposed this
idea because they desired to protect the integrity of the Nordic Games and
were concerned about a lack of facilities for winter sports.[8][9][10]

#### World War I

The idea was resurrected for the [1916 Games](/wiki/1916_Summer_Olympics "1916
Summer Olympics"), which were to be held in [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin"),
Germany. A winter sports week with [speed skating](/wiki/Speed_skating "Speed
skating"), figure skating, [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") and
[Nordic skiing](/wiki/Nordic_skiing "Nordic skiing") was planned, but the 1916
Olympics was cancelled after the outbreak of [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I
"World War I").[9]

#### 1920 to 1936

The first Olympics after the war, the [1920 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics "1920 Summer Olympics"), were held in
[Antwerp, Belgium](/wiki/Antwerp,_Belgium "Antwerp, Belgium"), and featured
figure skating and an ice hockey tournament.[9] Germany, Austria, Hungary,
Bulgaria and Turkey were banned from competing in the Games. At the [IOC
Congress](/wiki/List_of_IOC_meetings "List of IOC meetings") held the
following year it was decided that the host nation of the [1924 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1924_Summer_Olympics "1924 Summer Olympics"), France, would
host a separate "International Winter Sports Week" under the patronage of the
IOC. [Chamonix](/wiki/Chamonix "Chamonix") was chosen to host this "week"
(actually 11 days) of events. [The Games](/wiki/1924_Winter_Olympics "1924
Winter Olympics") proved to be a success when more than 250 athletes from 16
nations competed in 16 events.[11] Athletes [from
Finland](/wiki/Finland_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Finland at the 1924 Winter
Olympics") [and Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1924_Winter_Olympics "Norway at
the 1924 Winter Olympics") won 28 medals, more than the rest of the
participating nations combined.[12] Germany remained banned until 1925, and
instead hosted a series of games called [Deutsche
Kampfspiele](/wiki/Deutsche_Kampfspiele "Deutsche Kampfspiele"), starting with
the winter edition of 1922 (which predated the first Winter Olympics). In 1925
the IOC decided to create a separate winter event and the 1924 Games in
Chamonix was retroactively designated as the first Winter Olympics.[9][11]

[St. Moritz](/wiki/St._Moritz "St. Moritz"), Switzerland, was appointed by the
IOC to host the [second Winter Games](/wiki/1928_Winter_Olympics "1928 Winter
Olympics") in 1928.[13] Fluctuating weather conditions challenged the hosts.
The [opening ceremony](/wiki/Olympic_Games_ceremony "Olympic Games ceremony")
was held in a blizzard while warm weather conditions plagued sporting events
throughout the rest of the Games.[14] Because of the weather the 10,000 metre
speed-skating event had to be abandoned and officially cancelled.[15] The
weather was not the only noteworthy aspect of the 1928 Games: [Sonja
Henie](/wiki/Sonja_Henie "Sonja Henie") of
[Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1928_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 1928 Winter
Olympics") made history when she won the [figure
skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_1928_Winter_Olympics "Figure skating at
the 1928 Winter Olympics") competition at the age of 15. She became the
youngest Olympic champion in history, a distinction she held for 70 years.[16]

The [next Winter Olympics](/wiki/1932_Winter_Olympics "1932 Winter Olympics")
held in Lake Placid, New York, was the first to be hosted outside of Europe.
Seventeen nations and 252 athletes participated.[17] This was less than in
1928, as the journey to [Lake Placid](/wiki/Lake_Placid,_New_York "Lake
Placid, New York"), United States, was long and expensive for most
competitors, who had little money in the midst of the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression"). The athletes competed
in fourteen events in four sports.[17] Virtually no snow fell for two months
before the Games, and there was not enough snow to hold all the events until
mid-January.[18] Sonja Henie defended her Olympic title, and [Eddie
Eagan](/wiki/Eddie_Eagan "Eddie Eagan") of the United States, who had been an
Olympic champion in boxing in 1920, won the gold medal in the [men's bobsleigh
event](/wiki/Bobsleigh_at_the_1932_Winter_Olympics "Bobsleigh at the 1932
Winter Olympics") to become the first, and so far only, Olympian to have won
gold medals in both the [Summer](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic
Games") and Winter Olympics.[17]

The German towns of [Garmisch and Partenkirchen](/wiki/Garmisch-Partenkirchen
"Garmisch-Partenkirchen") joined to organise the [1936
edition](/wiki/1936_Winter_Olympics "1936 Winter Olympics") of the Winter
Games, held on 6–16 February.[19] This was the last time the
[Summer](/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics "1936 Summer Olympics") and Winter
Olympics were held in the same country in the same year. [Alpine
skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_1936_Winter_Olympics "Alpine skiing at the
1936 Winter Olympics") made its Olympic debut, but skiing teachers were barred
from entering because they were considered to be professionals.[20] Because of
this decision [the Swiss](/wiki/Switzerland_at_the_1936_Winter_Olympics
"Switzerland at the 1936 Winter Olympics") [and
Austrian](/wiki/Austria_at_the_1936_Winter_Olympics "Austria at the 1936
Winter Olympics") skiers refused to compete at the Games.[20]

#### World War II

[World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") interrupted the holding of
the Winter Olympics. The [1940 Games](/wiki/1940_Winter_Olympics "1940 Winter
Olympics") had been awarded to [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), Japan, but
the decision was rescinded in 1938 because of the Japanese
[invasion](/wiki/Sino-Japanese_War_\(1937-1945\) "Sino-Japanese War
\(1937-1945\)") of China. The Games were then to be held at Garmisch-
Partenkirchen, Germany, but the 1940 Games were cancelled following the German
[invasion of Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of Poland") in
1939.[21] Due to the ongoing war, the [1944 Games](/wiki/1944_Winter_Olympics
"1944 Winter Olympics"), originally scheduled for [Cortina
D'Ampezzo](/wiki/Cortina_D%27Ampezzo "Cortina D'Ampezzo"), Italy, were
cancelled.[22]

#### 1948 to 1960

[![An open air arena with crowds in the stands and people on the playing field
surrounding a
rostrum](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/74/1956_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremonies.jpg/170px-1956_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremonies.jpg)](/wiki/File:1956_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremonies.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1956_Winter_Olympics_opening_ceremonies.jpg "Enlarge")

The opening ceremonies of the 1956 Winter Olympics in Cortina d'Ampezzo

St. Moritz was selected to host the [first post-war Games in
1948](/wiki/1948_Winter_Olympics "1948 Winter Olympics"). Switzerland's
neutrality had protected the town during World War II, and most of the venues
were in place from the 1928 Games, which made St. Moritz a logical choice. It
became the first city to host a Winter Olympics twice.[23] Twenty-eight
countries competed in Switzerland, but athletes from Germany and Japan were
not invited.[24] Controversy erupted when two hockey teams from the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_at_the_1948_Winter_Olympics "United States at the
1948 Winter Olympics") arrived, both claiming to be the legitimate U.S.
Olympic hockey representative. The [Olympic flag](/wiki/Olympic_flag#Flag
"Olympic flag") presented at the [1920 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1920_Summer_Olympics "1920 Summer Olympics") in Antwerp was
stolen, as was its replacement. There was unprecedented parity at these Games,
during which 10 countries won gold medals—more than any Games to that
point.[25]

The [Olympic Flame](/wiki/Olympic_Flame "Olympic Flame") for the [1952
Games](/wiki/1952_Winter_Olympics "1952 Winter Olympics") in [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo
"Oslo"), was lit in the fireplace by skiing pioneer [Sondre
Nordheim](/wiki/Sondre_Nordheim "Sondre Nordheim"), and the torch relay was
conducted by 94 participants entirely on skis.[26][27] [Bandy](/wiki/Bandy
"Bandy"), a popular sport in the Nordic countries, was featured as a
demonstration sport, though [only
Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1952_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 1952 Winter
Olympics"), [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_at_the_1952_Winter_Olympics "Sweden at the
1952 Winter Olympics"), [and
Finland](/wiki/Finland_at_the_1952_Winter_Olympics "Finland at the 1952 Winter
Olympics") fielded teams. Norwegian athletes won 17 medals, which outpaced all
the other nations.[28] They were led by [Hjalmar
Andersen](/wiki/Hjalmar_Andersen "Hjalmar Andersen") who won three gold medals
in four events in the [speed
skating](/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1952_Winter_Olympics "Speed skating at the
1952 Winter Olympics") competition.[29]

After not being able to host the Games in 1944, Cortina d'Ampezzo was selected
to organise the [1956 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics "1956 Winter
Olympics"). At the opening ceremonies the final torch bearer, Guido Caroli,
entered the [Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Stadio_Olympica "Stadio Olympica") on ice
skates. As he skated around the stadium his skate caught on a cable and he
fell, nearly extinguishing the flame. He was able to recover and light the
cauldron.[30] These were the first Winter Games to be televised, and the first
Olympics ever broadcast to an international audience, though no television
rights were sold until the [1960 Summer Olympics](/wiki/1960_Summer_Olympics
"1960 Summer Olympics") in [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome").[31] The Cortina Games
were used to test the feasibility of televising large sporting events.[31] The
[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_1956_Winter_Olympics "Soviet Union at
the 1956 Winter Olympics") made its Olympic debut and had an immediate impact,
winning more medals than any other nation.[32] Soviet immediate success might
be explained by the advent of the state-sponsored "full-time amateur athlete".
The [USSR](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_Olympics "Soviet Union at the Olympics")
entered teams of athletes who were all nominally students, soldiers, or
working in a profession, but many of whom were in reality paid by the state to
train full-time.[33][34] [Chiharu Igaya](/wiki/Chiharu_Igaya "Chiharu Igaya")
won the first Winter Olympics medal [for
Japan](/wiki/Japan_at_the_1956_Winter_Olympics "Japan at the 1956 Winter
Olympics") and the continent of Asia when he placed second in the slalom.[35]

The IOC awarded the [1960 Olympics](/wiki/1960_Winter_Olympics "1960 Winter
Olympics") to [Squaw Valley](/wiki/Squaw_Valley_Ski_Resort "Squaw Valley Ski
Resort"), United States. It was an undeveloped resort in 1955, so from 1956 to
1960 the infrastructure and all of the venues were built at a cost of
US$80,000,000.[36][37] The opening and closing ceremonies were produced by
[Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney").[38] The Squaw Valley Olympics
was the first Winter Games to have a dedicated athletes' village,[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] the
first to use a computer (courtesy of [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM")) to tabulate
results, and the first to feature female speed skating events. The bobsleigh
events were absent for the only time due to the cost of building a bobsleigh
run.[38]

#### 1964 to 1980

[![An empty arena with the sheet of ice and the score
board](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Miracle_on_Ice.jpg/200px-
Miracle_on_Ice.jpg)](/wiki/File:Miracle_on_Ice.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Miracle_on_Ice.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Herb Brooks Arena](/wiki/Herb_Brooks_Arena "Herb Brooks Arena")  
in [Lake Placid](/wiki/Lake_Placid,_New_York "Lake Placid, New York") (c.
2007), site of  
the "[Miracle on Ice](/wiki/Miracle_on_Ice "Miracle on Ice")" in
[1980](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey at the 1980
Winter Olympics")

The Austrian city of [Innsbruck](/wiki/Innsbruck "Innsbruck") was the host in
[1964](/wiki/1964_Winter_Olympics "1964 Winter Olympics"). Although Innsbruck
was a traditional winter sports resort, warm weather caused a lack of snow
during the Games and the Austrian army was enlisted to transport snow and ice
to the sports venues.[38]
[Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_1964_Winter_Olympics "Soviet Union at the
1964 Winter Olympics") speed-skater [Lidia Skoblikova](/wiki/Lidia_Skoblikova
"Lidia Skoblikova") made history by winning all four speed skating events. Her
career total of six gold medals set a record for Winter Olympics athletes.[38]
[Luge](/wiki/Luge "Luge") was first contested in 1964, but the sport received
bad publicity when a competitor was killed in a pre-Olympic training
run.[39][40]

Held in the French town of [Grenoble](/wiki/Grenoble "Grenoble"), the [1968
Winter Olympics](/wiki/1968_Winter_Olympics "1968 Winter Olympics") were the
first Olympic Games to be broadcast in colour. There were 1,158 athletes from
37 nations competing in 35 events.[41]
[French](/wiki/France_at_the_1968_Winter_Olympics "France at the 1968 Winter
Olympics") alpine ski racer [Jean-Claude Killy](/wiki/Jean-Claude_Killy "Jean-
Claude Killy") became only the second person to win all the men's alpine
skiing events. The organising committee sold television rights for US$2
million, which was more than twice the cost of the broadcast rights for the
Innsbruck Games.[42] Venues were spread over long distances requiring three
athletes' villages. The organisers claimed that this was necessary to
accommodate technological advances, however critics disputed this, alleging
that the layout would incorporate the best possible venues for television
broadcasts at the athletes' expense.[42]

The [1972 Winter Games](/wiki/1972_Winter_Olympics "1972 Winter Olympics"),
held in [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), Japan, were the first to be hosted
on a continent other than North America or Europe. The issue of
professionalism was disputed during these Games when a number of alpine skiers
were found to have participated in a ski camp at [Mammoth
Mountain](/wiki/Mammoth_Mountain "Mammoth Mountain") in the United States;
three days before the opening ceremony, IOC president [Avery
Brundage](/wiki/Avery_Brundage "Avery Brundage") threatened to bar the skiers
from competing in the Games as he insisted that they were no longer amateurs
having benefited financially from their status as athletes.[43] Eventually
only [Austrian](/wiki/Austria_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics "Austria at the 1972
Winter Olympics") [Karl Schranz](/wiki/Karl_Schranz "Karl Schranz"), who
earned more than the other skiers, was excluded from the competition.[44]
Canada did not send teams to the
[1972](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey at the 1972
Winter Olympics") or [1976 ice hockey
tournaments](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_1976_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey at the
1976 Winter Olympics") in protest at not being able to use players from
professional leagues.[45] [Francisco Fernández
Ochoa](/wiki/Francisco_Fern%C3%A1ndez_Ochoa "Francisco Fernández Ochoa")
became the first (and, as of 2018, only)
[Spaniard](/wiki/Spain_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics "Spain at the 1972 Winter
Olympics") to win a Winter Olympic gold medal when he triumphed in the
[slalom](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics "Alpine skiing at the
1972 Winter Olympics").[46]

The [1976 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1976_Winter_Olympics "1976 Winter Olympics")
had initially been awarded in 1970 to [Denver](/wiki/Denver "Denver"),
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado") in the United States. These Games would
have coincided with the year of Colorado's [centennial](/wiki/Centennial
"Centennial") and the [United States
Bicentennial](/wiki/United_States_Bicentennial "United States Bicentennial").
However, in November 1972 the people of Colorado voted against public funding
of the Games by a 3:2 margin.[47][48] The IOC responded by offering the Games
to [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver")-[Garibaldi](/wiki/Garibaldi_Ranges
"Garibaldi Ranges"), British Columbia, which had previously been an official
candidate for the 1976 Games. However, a change in the provincial government
resulted in an administration that did not support the Olympic bid, so the
IOC's offer was rejected. [Salt Lake City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City "Salt Lake
City"), previously a candidate for the 1972 Winter Olympics, then put itself
forward, but the IOC opted instead to invite Innsbruck to host the 1976 Games,
as most of the infrastructure from the 1964 Games had been maintained. Despite
only having half the usual time to prepare for the Games, Innsbruck accepted
the invitation to replace Denver in February 1973.[49] Two Olympic flames were
lit because it was the second time that the Austrian town had hosted the
Winter Games.[49] The 1976 Games featured the first [combination bobsleigh and
luge track](/wiki/Igls_bobsleigh,_luge,_and_skeleton_track "Igls bobsleigh,
luge, and skeleton track"), in neighbouring Igls.[46] The [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_1976_Winter_Olympics "Soviet Union at the
1976 Winter Olympics") won its fourth consecutive ice hockey gold medal.[49]

[In 1980](/wiki/1980_Winter_Olympics "1980 Winter Olympics") the Winter
Olympics returned to Lake Placid, which had hosted the 1932 Games. The first
[boycott](/wiki/Boycott "Boycott") of a Winter Olympics took place at these
Games, when [Taiwan](/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_at_the_Olympics "Chinese Taipei at
the Olympics") refused to participate after an edict by the IOC mandated that
they change their name and national anthem.[50] This was an attempt by the IOC
to accommodate [China](/wiki/China_at_the_Olympics "China at the Olympics"),
who wished to compete using the same name and anthem as those used by
Taiwan.[50] As a result, [China](/wiki/China_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics
"China at the 1980 Winter Olympics") participated for the first time since
[1952](/wiki/1952_Summer_Olympics "1952 Summer Olympics").
[American](/wiki/United_States_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics "United States at
the 1980 Winter Olympics") speed-skater [Eric Heiden](/wiki/Eric_Heiden "Eric
Heiden") set either an Olympic or World record in every one of the five
[events](/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics "Speed skating at the
1980 Winter Olympics") in which he competed, winning a total of five
individual gold medals and breaking the record for most individual golds in a
single Olympics (both Summer and Winter).[51] [Hanni
Wenzel](/wiki/Hanni_Wenzel "Hanni Wenzel") won both the slalom and giant
slalom and her country,
[Liechtenstein](/wiki/Liechtenstein_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics "Liechtenstein
at the 1980 Winter Olympics"), became the smallest nation to produce an
Olympic gold medallist.[52] In the "[Miracle on Ice](/wiki/Miracle_on_Ice
"Miracle on Ice")", the [American hockey
team](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "United States
men's national ice hockey team") composed of college players beat the favoured
seasoned professionals from the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_ice_hockey_team "Soviet Union national ice
hockey team"), and progressed to eventually win the gold medal.[53][nb 4]

#### 1984 to 1998

[![Alberto Tomba in hat and ski
clothes](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Alberto_Tomba_Zagreb_2009.jpg/130px-
Alberto_Tomba_Zagreb_2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alberto_Tomba_Zagreb_2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Alberto_Tomba_Zagreb_2009.jpg "Enlarge")

Alberto Tomba, winner of five Olympic medals in Calgary, Albertville and
Lillehammer

[Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), Japan, and [Gothenburg](/wiki/Gothenburg
"Gothenburg"), Sweden, were front-runners to host the [1984 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1984_Winter_Olympics "1984 Winter Olympics"). It was therefore
a surprise when [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo"), Yugoslavia, was
selected as host.[56] The Games were well-organised and not affected by the
run-up to the [war](/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War") that engulfed the country
eight years later.[57] A total of 49 nations and 1,272 athletes participated
in 39 events. Host nation Yugoslavia won its first Olympic medal when alpine
skier [Jure Franko](/wiki/Jure_Franko "Jure Franko") won silver in the giant
slalom. Another sporting highlight was the free dance performance of
[British](/wiki/Great_Britain_at_the_1984_Winter_Olympics "Great Britain at
the 1984 Winter Olympics") ice dancers [Jayne Torvill](/wiki/Jayne_Torvill
"Jayne Torvill") and [Christopher Dean](/wiki/Christopher_Dean "Christopher
Dean"); their _[Boléro](/wiki/Bol%C3%A9ro "Boléro")_ routine received
unanimous perfect scores for artistic impression, earning them the gold
medal.[57]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Olympic_Torch_Calgary_1988.jpg/120px-
Olympic_Torch_Calgary_1988.jpg)](/wiki/File:Olympic_Torch_Calgary_1988.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Olympic_Torch_Calgary_1988.jpg "Enlarge")

The Olympic Torch from the [1988 Winter Olympic
Games](/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympic_Games "1988 Winter Olympic Games") in
[Calgary](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary")

In 1988, the Canadian city of [Calgary](/wiki/Calgary "Calgary") hosted the
[first Winter Olympics](/wiki/1988_Winter_Olympics "1988 Winter Olympics") to
span three weekends, lasting for a total of 16 days.[58] New events were added
in ski-jumping and speed skating, while future Olympic sports curling, [short
track speed skating](/wiki/Short_track_speed_skating "Short track speed
skating") and [freestyle skiing](/wiki/Freestyle_skiing "Freestyle skiing")
made their debut appearance as demonstration sports. The speed skating events
were held indoors for the first time, on the [Olympic Oval](/wiki/Olympic_Oval
"Olympic Oval"). Dutch skater [Yvonne van Gennip](/wiki/Yvonne_van_Gennip
"Yvonne van Gennip") won three gold medals and set two world records, beating
skaters from the favoured [East German
team](/wiki/East_Germany_at_the_1988_Winter_Olympics "East Germany at the 1988
Winter Olympics") in every race.[59] Her medal total was equalled by
[Finnish](/wiki/Finland_at_the_1988_Winter_Olympics "Finland at the 1988
Winter Olympics") ski jumper [Matti Nykänen](/wiki/Matti_Nyk%C3%A4nen "Matti
Nykänen"), who won all three events in his sport. [Alberto
Tomba](/wiki/Alberto_Tomba "Alberto Tomba"), [an
Italian](/wiki/Italy_at_the_1988_Winter_Olympics "Italy at the 1988 Winter
Olympics") skier, made his Olympic debut by winning both the giant slalom and
slalom. East German [Christa Rothenburger](/wiki/Christa_Luding-Rothenburger
"Christa Luding-Rothenburger") won the women's 1,000 metre speed skating
event. Seven months later she would earn a silver in track cycling at the
[Summer Games](/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics") in
[Seoul](/wiki/Seoul "Seoul"), to become the only athlete to win medals in both
a Summer and Winter Olympics in the same year.[58]

The [1992 Winter Games](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter Olympics")
were the last to be held in the same year as the [Summer
Games](/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics "1992 Summer Olympics").[60] They were
hosted in the French [Savoie](/wiki/Savoie "Savoie") region, with 18 events
held in the city of [Albertville](/wiki/Albertville "Albertville") and the
remaining events spread out over the Savoie.[60] Political changes of the time
were reflected in the composition of the Olympic teams competing in France:
this was the first Games to be held after the [fall of
Communism](/wiki/Fall_of_Communism "Fall of Communism") and the [fall of the
Berlin Wall](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall "Fall of the Berlin Wall"), and
Germany competed as a single nation for the first time since the 1964 Games;
former [Yugoslavian](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist
Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") republics
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_at_the_1992_Winter_Olympics "Croatia at the 1992
Winter Olympics") and [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia_at_the_1992_Winter_Olympics
"Slovenia at the 1992 Winter Olympics") made their debuts as independent
nations; most of the former [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
republics still competed as a single team known as the [Unified
Team](/wiki/Unified_Team_at_the_1992_Winter_Olympics "Unified Team at the 1992
Winter Olympics"), but the [Baltic States](/wiki/Baltic_States "Baltic
States") made independent appearances for the first time since before World
War II.[61] At 16 years old,
[Finnish](/wiki/Finland_at_the_1992_Winter_Olympics "Finland at the 1992
Winter Olympics") ski jumper [Toni Nieminen](/wiki/Toni_Nieminen "Toni
Nieminen") made history by becoming the youngest male Winter Olympic
champion.[62] [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_at_the_1992_Winter_Olympics "New
Zealand at the 1992 Winter Olympics") skier [Annelise
Coberger](/wiki/Annelise_Coberger "Annelise Coberger") became the first Winter
Olympic medallist from the southern hemisphere when she won a silver medal in
the women's slalom.

The [1994 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics "1994 Winter Olympics"),
held in [Lillehammer](/wiki/Lillehammer "Lillehammer"), Norway, were the first
Winter Games to be held separately from the Summer Games. This change resulted
from the decision reached in the [91st IOC Session
(1986)](/wiki/List_of_IOC_meetings#IOC_Sessions "List of IOC meetings") to
separate the Summer and Winter Games and place them in alternating even-
numbered years.[63] Lillehammer is the northernmost city to ever host the
Winter Games and it was the second time the Games were held in Norway, after
the [1952 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1952_Winter_Olympics "1952 Winter Olympics")
in [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo "Oslo"). After the [dissolution of
Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Dissolution_of_Czechoslovakia "Dissolution of
Czechoslovakia") in 1993, the [Czech
Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "Czech Republic at
the 1994 Winter Olympics") and
[Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "Slovakia at the 1994
Winter Olympics") made their Olympic debuts.[64] The women's figure skating
competition drew media attention when [American
skater](/wiki/United_States_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "United States at the
1994 Winter Olympics") [Nancy Kerrigan](/wiki/Nancy_Kerrigan "Nancy Kerrigan")
was injured on 6 January 1994, in an assault planned by the ex-husband of
opponent [Tonya Harding](/wiki/Tonya_Harding "Tonya Harding").[65] Both
skaters competed in the Games, but the gold medal was controversially won by
[Oksana Baiul](/wiki/Oksana_Baiul "Oksana Baiul") who became
[Ukraine's](/wiki/Ukraine_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "Ukraine at the 1994
Winter Olympics") first Olympic champion, while Kerrigan won the silver
medal.[66][67] [Johann Olav Koss](/wiki/Johann_Olav_Koss "Johann Olav Koss")
[of Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 1994
Winter Olympics") won three gold medals, coming first in all of the distance
speed skating events.[68] 13-year-old [Kim Yoon-Mi](/wiki/Kim_Yun-
Mi_\(speed_skater\) "Kim Yun-Mi \(speed skater\)") became the youngest-ever
Olympic gold medallist when South Korea won the women's 3,000 meter speed
skating relay. [Russia](/wiki/Russia_at_the_1994_Winter_Olympics "Russia at
the 1994 Winter Olympics") won the most events, with eleven gold medals, while
Norway achieved 26 podium finishes, collecting the most medals overall on home
ground. [Juan Antonio Samaranch](/wiki/Juan_Antonio_Samaranch "Juan Antonio
Samaranch") described Lillehammer as "the best Olympic Winter Games ever" in
his closing ceremony speech.[69]

The [1998 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter Olympics")
were held in the Japanese city of [Nagano](/wiki/Nagano "Nagano") and were the
first Games to host more than 2,000 athletes.[70] The men's [ice hockey
tournament](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey at the Winter
Olympics") was opened to professionals for the first time.
[Canada](/wiki/Canada_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Canada men's national
ice hockey team") and the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "United States
men's national ice hockey team") were favoured to win the tournament as they
both fielded numerous [NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey
League") players,[70] but surprisingly neither team won any medals and it was
the [Czech Republic](/wiki/Czech_Republic_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team
"Czech Republic men's national ice hockey team") who prevailed.[70] Women's
ice hockey made its debut and the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_women%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "United States
women's national ice hockey team") won the gold medal.[71] [Bjørn
Dæhlie](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rn_D%C3%A6hlie "Bjørn Dæhlie") of
[Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 1998 Winter
Olympics") won three gold medals in Nordic skiing, becoming the most decorated
Winter Olympic athlete, with eight gold medals and twelve medals
overall.[70][72] [Austrian](/wiki/Austria_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics "Austria
at the 1998 Winter Olympics") [Hermann Maier](/wiki/Hermann_Maier "Hermann
Maier") survived a crash during the downhill competition and returned to win
gold in the
[super-G](/wiki/Alpine_skiing_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_super-G
"Alpine skiing at the 1998 Winter Olympics – Men's super-G") and the giant
slalom.[70] [Tara Lipinski](/wiki/Tara_Lipinski "Tara Lipinski") of the
[United States](/wiki/United_States_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics "United States
at the 1998 Winter Olympics"), aged just 15, became the youngest ever female
gold medallist in an individual event when she won the [Ladies'
Singles](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics#Ladies "Figure
skating at the 1998 Winter Olympics"), a record that had stood since [Sonja
Henie](/wiki/Sonja_Henie "Sonja Henie") of
[Norway](/wiki/Norway_at_the_1928_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 1928 Winter
Olympics") won the same event, also aged 15, in [St. Moritz in
1928](/wiki/1928_Winter_Olympics "1928 Winter Olympics"). New world records
were set in [speed skating](/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1998_Winter_Olympics
"Speed skating at the 1998 Winter Olympics") largely due to the introduction
of the [clap skate](/wiki/Clap_skate "Clap skate").[73]

### 21st century

#### 2002 to 2010

[![Interwoven steel frame several stories high with the lit flame at the
top](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/2002_Winter_Olympics_flame.jpg/170px-2002_Winter_Olympics_flame.jpg)](/wiki/File:2002_Winter_Olympics_flame.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2002_Winter_Olympics_flame.jpg "Enlarge")

Olympic flame during the Opening Ceremony of the 2002 Games in Salt Lake City

The [2002 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics "2002 Winter Olympics")
were held in [Salt Lake City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City,_Utah "Salt Lake City,
Utah"), United States, hosting 77 nations and 2,399 athletes in 78 events in 7
sports.[74] These Games were the first to take place since the [September 11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") of 2001, which
meant a higher degree of security to avoid a terrorist attack. The opening
ceremony saw signs of the [aftermath of the events of that
day](/wiki/Aftermath_of_the_September_11_attacks "Aftermath of the September
11 attacks"), including the flag that flew at [Ground
Zero](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site "World Trade Center site"),
[NYPD](/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department "New York City Police
Department") officer [Daniel Rodríguez](/wiki/Daniel_Rodr%C3%ADguez_\(tenor\)
"Daniel Rodríguez \(tenor\)") singing "[God Bless
America](/wiki/God_Bless_America "God Bless America")", and honour guards of
NYPD and [FDNY](/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department "New York City Fire
Department") members.

[German](/wiki/Germany_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics "Germany at the 2002 Winter
Olympics") [Georg Hackl](/wiki/Georg_Hackl "Georg Hackl") won a silver in the
singles luge, becoming the first athlete in Olympic history to win medals in
the same individual event in five consecutive Olympics.[74]
[Canada](/wiki/Canada_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics "Canada at the 2002 Winter
Olympics") achieved an unprecedented double by winning both the men's and
women's [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics "Ice hockey
at the 2002 Winter Olympics") gold medals.[74] Canada became embroiled with
[Russia](/wiki/Russia_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics "Russia at the 2002 Winter
Olympics") in a
[controversy](/wiki/2002_Olympic_Winter_Games_figure_skating_scandal "2002
Olympic Winter Games figure skating scandal") that involved the judging of the
[pairs figure skating](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics
"Figure skating at the 2002 Winter Olympics") competition. The Russian pair of
[Yelena Berezhnaya](/wiki/Yelena_Berezhnaya "Yelena Berezhnaya") and [Anton
Sikharulidze](/wiki/Anton_Sikharulidze "Anton Sikharulidze") competed against
the Canadian pair of [Jamie Salé](/wiki/Jamie_Sal%C3%A9 "Jamie Salé") and
[David Pelletier](/wiki/David_Pelletier "David Pelletier") for the gold medal.
The Canadians appeared to have skated well enough to win the competition, yet
the Russians were awarded the gold. The judging broke along [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") lines with judges from former
[Communist](/wiki/Communism "Communism") countries favouring the Russian pair
and judges from [Western](/wiki/Western_World "Western World") nations voting
for the Canadians. The only exception was the
[French](/wiki/France_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics "France at the 2002 Winter
Olympics") judge, [Marie-Reine Le Gougne](/wiki/Marie-Reine_Le_Gougne "Marie-
Reine Le Gougne"), who awarded the gold to the Russians. An investigation
revealed that she had been pressured to give the gold to the Russian pair
regardless of how they skated; in return the Russian judge would look
favourably on the French entrants in the ice dancing competition.[75] The IOC
decided to award both pairs the gold medal in a second [medal
ceremony](/wiki/Olympic_Games_ceremony "Olympic Games ceremony") held later in
the Games.[76] [Australian](/wiki/Australia_at_the_2002_Winter_Olympics
"Australia at the 2002 Winter Olympics") [Steven
Bradbury](/wiki/Steven_Bradbury_\(speed_skater\) "Steven Bradbury \(speed
skater\)") became the first gold medallist from the southern hemisphere when
he won the 1,000 metre short-track speed skating event.[77]

[![Close-up of the Olympic Flame during the 2006 Winter Olympics in
Turin](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Braciere_Olimpico.jpg/170px-
Braciere_Olimpico.jpg)](/wiki/File:Braciere_Olimpico.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Braciere_Olimpico.jpg "Enlarge")

Close-up of the Olympic Flame during the [2006 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics") in
[Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin")

The Italian city of [Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin") hosted the [2006 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics"). It was the
second time that Italy had hosted the Winter Olympic Games. [South
Korean](/wiki/South_Korea_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "South Korea at the 2006
Winter Olympics") athletes won 10 medals, including 6 gold in the short-track
speed skating events. [Sun-Yu Jin](/wiki/Jin_Sun-Yu "Jin Sun-Yu") won three
gold medals while her teammate [Hyun-Soo Ahn](/wiki/Hyun-Soo_Ahn "Hyun-Soo
Ahn") won three gold medals and a bronze.[78] In the women's [Cross-
Country](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "Cross-country
skiing at the 2006 Winter Olympics") team pursuit
[Canadian](/wiki/Canada_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "Canada at the 2006 Winter
Olympics") [Sara Renner](/wiki/Sara_Renner "Sara Renner") broke one of her
poles and, when he saw her dilemma,
[Norwegian](/wiki/Norway_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 2006
Winter Olympics") coach [Bjørnar
Håkensmoen](/wiki/Bj%C3%B8rnar_H%C3%A5kensmoen "Bjørnar Håkensmoen") decided
to lend her a pole. In so doing she was able to help her team win a silver
medal in the event at the expense of the Norwegian team, who finished
fourth.[78][79] On winning the Super-G, [Kjetil-Andre Aamodt](/wiki/Kjetil-
Andre_Aamodt "Kjetil-Andre Aamodt") of Norway became the most decorated ski
racer of all time with 4 gold and 8 overall medals. He is also the only ski
racer to have won the same event at three different Olympics, winning the
Super-G in [1992](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter Olympics"),
[2002](/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics "2002 Winter Olympics") and
[2006](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics"). [Claudia
Pechstein](/wiki/Claudia_Pechstein "Claudia Pechstein") of
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "Germany at the 2006
Winter Olympics") became the first speed skater to earn nine career
medals.[78] In February 2009, Pechstein tested positive for "blood
manipulation" and received a two-year suspension, which she appealed. The
[Court of Arbitration for Sport](/wiki/Court_of_Arbitration_for_Sport "Court
of Arbitration for Sport") upheld her suspension but a Swiss court ruled that
she could compete for a spot on the [2010 German Olympic
team](/wiki/Germany_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics "Germany at the 2010 Winter
Olympics").[80] This ruling was brought to the Swiss Federal Tribunal, which
overturned the lower court's ruling and precluded her from competing in
Vancouver.[81]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NodarKumaritashvili-
Memorial-Whistler-20100320.jpg/170px-NodarKumaritashvili-Memorial-
Whistler-20100320.jpg)](/wiki/File:NodarKumaritashvili-Memorial-
Whistler-20100320.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NodarKumaritashvili-Memorial-Whistler-20100320.jpg "Enlarge")

A memorial to Nodar Kumaritashvili in
[Whistler](/wiki/Whistler,_British_Columbia "Whistler, British Columbia"),
photographed on 20 March 2010

In 2003 the IOC awarded the [2010 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics
"2010 Winter Olympics") to [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), thus
allowing Canada to host its second Winter Olympics. With a population of more
than 2.5 million people Vancouver is the largest metropolitan area to ever
host a Winter Olympic Games.[82] Over 2,500 athletes from 82 countries
participated in 86 events.[83] The death of
[Georgian](/wiki/Georgia_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics "Georgia at the 2010
Winter Olympics") luger [Nodar Kumaritashvili](/wiki/Nodar_Kumaritashvili
"Nodar Kumaritashvili") in a training run on the day of the opening ceremonies
resulted in the [Whistler Sliding Centre](/wiki/Whistler_Sliding_Centre
"Whistler Sliding Centre") changing the track layout on safety grounds.[84]
[Norwegian](/wiki/Norway_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics "Norway at the 2010
Winter Olympics") cross-country skier [Marit Bjørgen](/wiki/Marit_Bj%C3%B8rgen
"Marit Bjørgen") won five medals in the six cross-country events on the
women's programme. She finished the Olympics with three golds, a silver and a
bronze.[85] The Vancouver Games were notable for the poor performance of the
[Russian](/wiki/Russia_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics "Russia at the 2010 Winter
Olympics") athletes. From their first Winter Olympics in
[1956](/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics "1956 Winter Olympics") to the 2006 Games, a
Soviet or Russian delegation had never been outside the top five medal-winning
nations, but in 2010 they finished sixth in total medals and eleventh in gold
medals. [President](/wiki/Russian_President "Russian President") [Dmitry
Medvedev](/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev "Dmitry Medvedev") called for the resignation
of top sports officials immediately after the Games.[86] Russia's
disappointing performance at Vancouver is cited as the reason behind the
[implementation of a doping scheme](/wiki/Doping_in_Russia "Doping in Russia")
alleged to have been in operation at major events such as the 2014 Games at
Sochi.[87] The success of Asian countries stood in stark contrast to the
under-performing Russian team, with Vancouver marking a high point for medals
won by Asian countries. In 1992 the Asian countries had won fifteen medals,
three of which were gold. In Vancouver the total number of medals won by
athletes from Asia had increased to thirty-one, with eleven of them being
gold. The rise of Asian nations in Winter Olympics sports is due in part to
the growth of winter sports programmes and the interest in winter sports in
nations such as South Korea, Japan and China.[88][89]

#### 2014 to 2018

[Sochi](/wiki/Sochi "Sochi"), Russia, was selected as the host city for the
[2014 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics "2014 Winter Olympics") over
[Salzburg](/wiki/Salzburg "Salzburg"), Austria, and
[Pyeongchang](/wiki/Pyeongchang_County "Pyeongchang County"), South Korea.
This was the first time that Russia had hosted a Winter Olympics.[90] The
Games took place from 7 to 23 February 2014.[91] A record 2,800 athletes from
88 countries competed in 98 events. The Olympic Village and Olympic Stadium
were located on the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") coast. All of the
mountain venues were 50 kilometres (31 miles) away in the alpine region known
as [Krasnaya Polyana](/wiki/Krasnaya_Polyana,_Sochi,_Krasnodar_Krai "Krasnaya
Polyana, Sochi, Krasnodar Krai").[90] The Games were the most expensive so
far, with a cost of £30 billion (USD 51 billion).

On the snow, Norwegian biathlete [Ole Einar
Bjørndalen](/wiki/Ole_Einar_Bj%C3%B8rndalen "Ole Einar Bjørndalen") took two
golds to bring his total tally of Olympic medals to 13, overtaking his
compatriot Bjørn Dæhlie to become the most decorated Winter Olympian of all
time. Another Norwegian, cross-country skier [Marit
Bjørgen](/wiki/Marit_Bj%C3%B8rgen "Marit Bjørgen") took three golds; her total
of ten Olympic medals tied her as the female Winter Olympian with most medals,
alongside [Raisa Smetanina](/wiki/Raisa_Smetanina "Raisa Smetanina") and
[Stefania Belmondo](/wiki/Stefania_Belmondo "Stefania Belmondo"). Snowboarder
[Ayumu Hirano](/wiki/Ayumu_Hirano "Ayumu Hirano") became the youngest
medallist on snow at the Winter Games when he took a silver in the
[halfpipe](/wiki/Snowboarding_at_the_2014_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_halfpipe
"Snowboarding at the 2014 Winter Olympics – Men's halfpipe") competition at
the age of fifteen. On the ice, the Dutch dominated the speed skating events,
taking 23 medals, four clean sweeps of the podium places and at least one
medal in each of the twelve medal events. [Ireen Wüst](/wiki/Ireen_W%C3%BCst
"Ireen Wüst") was their most successful competitor, taking two golds and three
silvers. In figure skating, [Yuzuru Hanyu](/wiki/Yuzuru_Hanyu "Yuzuru Hanyu")
became the first skater to break the 100-point barrier in the short programme
on the way to winning the gold medal. Among the sledding disciplines, luger
[Armin Zöggeler](/wiki/Armin_Z%C3%B6ggeler "Armin Zöggeler") took a bronze,
becoming the first Winter Olympian to secure a medal in six consecutive
Games.[90]

Following their disappointing performance at the 2010 Games, and an investment
of £600 million in elite sport,
[Russia](/wiki/Russia_at_the_2014_Winter_Olympics "Russia at the 2014 Winter
Olympics") initially topped the [medal
table](/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics_medal_table "2014 Winter Olympics medal
table"), taking 33 medals including thirteen golds.[92] However [Grigory
Rodchenkov](/wiki/Grigory_Rodchenkov "Grigory Rodchenkov"), the former head of
the Russian national anti-doping laboratory, subsequently claimed that he had
been involved in doping dozens of Russian competitors for the Games, and that
he had been assisted by the Russian [Federal Security
Service](/wiki/Federal_Security_Service "Federal Security Service") in opening
and re-sealing bottles containing urine samples so that samples with banned
substances could be replaced with "clean" urine. A subsequent
[investigation](/wiki/McLaren_Report "McLaren Report") commissioned by the
[World Anti-Doping Agency](/wiki/World_Anti-Doping_Agency "World Anti-Doping
Agency") led by [Richard McLaren](/wiki/Richard_McLaren_\(academic\) "Richard
McLaren \(academic\)") concluded that a state-sponsored doping programme had
operated in Russia from "at least late 2011 to 2015" across the "vast
majority" of Summer and Winter Olympic sports.[93] On 5 December 2017, the IOC
announced that [Russia](/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee "Russian Olympic
Committee") would be banned from the 2018 Winter Olympics with immediate
effect[94] and by the end of 2017 the [IOC Disciplinary
Commission](/wiki/Oswald_Commission "Oswald Commission") had disqualified 43
Russian athletes, stripping thirteen medals and knocking Russia from the top
of the medal table, thus putting Norway in the lead.[95][96][97]

On 6 July 2011, [Pyeongchang](/wiki/Pyeongchang_County "Pyeongchang County"),
South Korea, was selected to host the [2018 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics "2018 Winter Olympics") over
[Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), Germany, and [Annecy](/wiki/Annecy "Annecy"),
France.[98] This was the first time that [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea
"South Korea") had been selected to host a Winter Olympics and it was the
second time the Olympics were held in the country overall, after the [1988
Summer Olympics in Seoul](/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics "1988 Summer Olympics").
The Games took place from 9 to 25 February 2018. More than 2,900 athletes from
92 countries participated in 102 events. The Olympic Stadium and many of the
sports venues were situated in the [Alpensia Resort](/wiki/Alpensia_Resort
"Alpensia Resort") in [Daegwallyeong-myeon](/wiki/Daegwallyeong-myeon
"Daegwallyeong-myeon"), Pyeongchang, while a number of other sports venues
were located in the [Gangneung Olympic Park](/wiki/Gangneung_Olympic_Park
"Gangneung Olympic Park") in Pyeongchang's neighboring city of
[Gangneung](/wiki/Gangneung "Gangneung").

The lead-up to the 2018 Winter Olympics was affected by [the tensions between
North and South Korea](/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics#North_Korean_relations "2018
Winter Olympics") and the ongoing [Russian doping
scandal](/wiki/Doping_in_Russia "Doping in Russia"). Despite [tense
relations](/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations "North Korea–South
Korea relations"), [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") agreed to
[participate](/wiki/North_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "North Korea at
the 2018 Winter Olympics") in the Games, enter with South Korea during the
opening ceremony as a [unified Korea](/wiki/Unified_Korea "Unified Korea"),
and field a [unified team](/wiki/Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "Korea at
the 2018 Winter Olympics") in [women's ice
hockey](/wiki/Korea_women%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Korea women's national
ice hockey team"). Individual Russian athletes, who qualified and could
demonstrate they had complied with the IOC's doping regulations, were given
the option to compete neutrally in Pyeongchang as "Olympic Athletes from
Russia" (OAR) but they were not allowed to compete under the Russian flag.[94]

The Games saw the addition of [big air
snowboarding](/wiki/Snowboarding#Big_air "Snowboarding"), [mass
start](/wiki/Mass_start "Mass start") [speed skating](/wiki/Speed_skating
"Speed skating"), [mixed doubles curling](/wiki/Mixed_doubles_curling "Mixed
doubles curling"), and mixed team [alpine skiing](/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine
skiing") to the programme. On the ice, the Netherlands again dominated the
speed skating, winning gold medals in seven of the ten individual events.
Dutch speed skater [Sven Kramer](/wiki/Sven_Kramer "Sven Kramer") won gold in
the men's 5000m event, becoming the only male speed skater to win the same
Olympic event three times. On the snow, Norway led the medal tally in cross-
country skiing, with [Marit Bjørgen](/wiki/Marit_Bj%C3%B8rgen "Marit Bjørgen")
winning bronze in the women's team sprint and gold in the 30 kilometre
classical event, bringing her total Olympic medal haul to fifteen, the most
won by any athlete (male or female) in Winter Olympics history. [Johannes
Høsflot Klæbo](/wiki/Johannes_H%C3%B8sflot_Kl%C3%A6bo "Johannes Høsflot
Klæbo") became the youngest ever male to win an Olympic gold in cross-country
skiing when he won the [men's sprint](/wiki/Cross-
country_skiing_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_sprint "Cross-
country skiing at the 2018 Winter Olympics – Men's sprint") at age 21.
[Noriaki Kasai](/wiki/Noriaki_Kasai "Noriaki Kasai") of Japan became the first
athlete in history to participate in eight Winter Olympics when he took part
in the ski jumping qualification the day before the opening of the Games.
[Ester Ledecká](/wiki/Ester_Ledeck%C3%A1 "Ester Ledecká") of the Czech
Republic won gold in the skiing super-G event and another gold in the
snowboarding parallel giant slalom, making her the first female athlete to win
Olympic gold medals in two different sports at a single Winter Games.

Norway led the total medal standings with 39, the highest number of medals by
a nation in any Winter Olympics, followed by Germany's 31 and Canada's 29.
Host nation [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics "South
Korea at the 2018 Winter Olympics") won seventeen medals, their highest medal
haul at a Winter Olympics.

#### Future

The host city for the [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics "2022
Winter Olympics"), is [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing") in northern China,
elected on 31 July 2015, at the [128th](/wiki/128th_IOC_Session "128th IOC
Session") [IOC Session](/wiki/IOC_Session "IOC Session") in [Kuala
Lumpur](/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur "Kuala Lumpur"). Beijing will be the first city
ever to have hosted both the Summer and Winter Olympics. The 2022 Winter
Olympics will take place between 4 and 20 February 2022.

## Controversy

Main article: [Olympic Games scandals and controversies § Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Olympic_Games_scandals_and_controversies#Winter_Olympics
"Olympic Games scandals and controversies")

[![a head shot of Juan Antonio Samaranch with dark glasses
on](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Juan_Antonio_Samaranch_DF-
ST-01-00128.jpg/170px-Juan_Antonio_Samaranch_DF-
ST-01-00128.jpg)](/wiki/File:Juan_Antonio_Samaranch_DF-ST-01-00128.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Juan_Antonio_Samaranch_DF-ST-01-00128.jpg "Enlarge")

Juan Antonio Samaranch, former IOC president, was implicated in a bidding
scandal for the 2002 Winter Olympics.

The process for awarding host city honours came under intense scrutiny after
[Salt Lake City](/wiki/Salt_Lake_City "Salt Lake City") had been awarded the
right to host the 2002 Games.[99] Soon after the host city had been announced
it was discovered that the organisers had engaged in an elaborate bribery
[scheme](/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympic_bid_scandal "2002 Winter Olympic bid
scandal") to curry favour with IOC officials.[99] Gifts and other financial
considerations were given to those who would evaluate and vote on Salt Lake
City's bid. These gifts included medical treatment for relatives, a college
scholarship for one member's son and a land deal in Utah. Even IOC president
[Juan Antonio Samaranch](/wiki/Juan_Antonio_Samaranch "Juan Antonio
Samaranch") received two rifles valued at $2,000. Samaranch defended the gift
as inconsequential since, as president, he was a non-voting member.[100] The
subsequent investigation uncovered inconsistencies in the bids for every
Olympics (both Summer and Winter) since 1988.[101] For example, the gifts
received by IOC members from the Japanese Organising Committee for Nagano's
bid for the [1998 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter
Olympics") were described by the investigation committee as
"astronomical".[102] Although nothing strictly illegal had been done, the IOC
feared that corporate sponsors would lose faith in the integrity of the
process and that the Olympic brand would be tarnished to such an extent that
advertisers would begin to pull their support.[103] The investigation resulted
in the expulsion of 10 IOC members and the sanctioning of another 10. New
terms and age limits were established for IOC membership, and 15 former
Olympic athletes were added to the committee. Stricter rules for future bids
were imposed, with ceilings imposed on the value of gifts IOC members could
accept from bid cities.[104][105][106]

### Host city legacy

According to the IOC, the host city for the Winter Olympics is responsible for
"...establishing functions and services for all aspects of the Games, such as
sports planning, venues, finance, technology, accommodation, catering, media
services, etc., as well as operations during the Games."[107] Due to the cost
of hosting the Games, most host cities never realise a profit on their
investment.[108] For example, the [2006 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics") in
[Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin"), Italy, cost $3.6 billion to host. By comparison,
the [1998 Winter Olympics](/wiki/1998_Winter_Olympics "1998 Winter Olympics")
in [Nagano](/wiki/Nagano "Nagano"), Japan, cost $12.5 billion.[109] The
organisers of the Nagano Games claimed that the cost of extending the [bullet
train](/wiki/Shinkansen "Shinkansen") service from [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo
"Tokyo") to [Nagano](/wiki/Nagano "Nagano") was responsible for the large
price tag.[109] The organising committee had hoped that the exposure gained
from hosting the Winter Olympics, and the improved access to Nagano from
Tokyo, would benefit the local economy for years afterwards. In actual fact,
Nagano's economy did experience a post-Olympic boom for a year or two, but the
long-term effects have not materialised as anticipated.[109] The likelihood of
heavy debt is a deterrent to prospective host cities, as well as the prospect
of unused sports venues and infrastructure saddling the local community with
upkeep costs into the future with no appreciable post-Olympic value.[110]

The Winter Olympics has the added problem of the alpine events requiring a
mountain location; the men's downhill needs an 800 meter altitude difference
along a suitable course. As this is a focal event that is central to the
Games, the IOC will not agree to it taking place a great distance from the
main host city.[111] The requirement for a mountain location also means that
venues such as hockey arenas often have to be built in sparsely populated
areas with little future need for a large arena. Due to cost issues, the only
candidate cities for the [2022 Winter Olympics](/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics
"2022 Winter Olympics") were in dictatorship countries, and a number of
European countries declined due to political doubt over costs. Both the
[2006](/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics "2006 Winter Olympics") and
[2010](/wiki/2010_Winter_Olympics "2010 Winter Olympics") Games, which were
hosted in countries where large cities are located close to suitable mountain
regions, had lower costs since more venues and transport infrastructure
already existed.

The IOC has enacted several initiatives to mitigate these concerns. Firstly,
the commission has agreed to fund part of the host city's budget for staging
the Games.[112] Secondly, the qualifying host countries are limited to those
that have the resources and infrastructure to successfully host an Olympic
Games without negatively impacting the region or nation; this consequently
rules out a large portion of the developing world.[113] Finally, any
prospective host city planning to bid for the Games is required to add a
"legacy plan" to their proposal, with a view to the long-term economic and
environmental impact that hosting the Olympics will have on the region.[114]

### Doping

In 1967 the IOC began enacting drug testing protocols. They started by
randomly testing athletes at the 1968 Winter Olympics.[115] The first Winter
Games athlete to test positive for a banned substance was [Alois
Schloder](/wiki/Alois_Schloder "Alois Schloder"), a [West
German](/wiki/West_Germany_at_the_1972_Winter_Olympics "West Germany at the
1972 Winter Olympics") hockey player,[116] but his team was still allowed to
compete.[117] During the 1970s testing outside of competition was escalated
because it was found to deter athletes from using performance-enhancing
drugs.[118] The problem with testing during this time was a lack of
standardisation of the test procedures, which undermined the credibility of
the tests. It was not until the late 1980s that international sporting
federations began to coordinate efforts to standardise the drug-testing
protocols.[119] The IOC took the lead in the fight against steroids when it
established the independent [World Anti-Doping Agency](/wiki/World_Anti-
Doping_Agency "World Anti-Doping Agency") (WADA) in November 1999.[120][121]

The 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin became notable for a scandal involving the
emerging trend of [blood doping](/wiki/Blood_doping "Blood doping"), the use
of blood transfusions or synthetic hormones such as
[Erythropoietin](/wiki/Erythropoietin "Erythropoietin") (EPO) to improve
oxygen flow and thus reduce fatigue.[122] The Italian police conducted a raid
on the [Austrian](/wiki/Austria_at_the_2006_Winter_Olympics "Austria at the
2006 Winter Olympics") cross-country ski team's residence during the Games
where they seized blood-doping specimens and equipment.[123] This event
followed the pre-Olympics suspension of 12 cross-country skiers who tested
positive for unusually high levels of [haemoglobin](/wiki/Hemoglobin
"Hemoglobin"), which is evidence of blood doping.[122]

The 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi's Russian Doping Scandal has resulted in the
International Olympic Committee to begin disciplinary proceedings against 28
(later increased to 46) Russian athletes who competed at the 2014 Winter Games
in Sochi, Russia, acting on evidence that their urine samples were tampered
with.[124][125][126][127][128]

## Politics

### Cold War

[![A postage stamp with a blue background and two figure skaters skating, the
date 1968 is centered on the top of the stamp along with the Olympic rings.
The word "Winterspiele" is written down the right side, the words "X
Olympische" are written down the left side. The number 25 is in the lower left
corner and the letters "DDR" are in the lower right
corner](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1968%2C_MiNr_1339.jpg/170px-
Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1968%2C_MiNr_1339.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1968,_MiNr_1339.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1968,_MiNr_1339.jpg "Enlarge")

A postage stamp issued by East Germany in 1968 in commemoration of their first
Winter Olympics as an independent country

The Winter Olympics have been an ideological front in the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") since the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_1956_Winter_Olympics "Soviet Union at the
1956 Winter Olympics") first participated at the [1956 Winter
Games](/wiki/1956_Winter_Olympics "1956 Winter Olympics"). It did not take
long for the Cold War combatants to discover what a powerful propaganda tool
the Olympic Games could be. The advent of the state-sponsored "full-time
amateur athlete" of the [Eastern Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc")
countries further eroded the ideology of the pure amateur, as it put the self-
financed amateurs of the Western countries at a disadvantage. The [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_at_the_Olympics "Soviet Union at the Olympics")
entered teams of athletes who were all nominally students, soldiers, or
working in a profession, but many of whom were in reality paid by the state to
train on a full-time basis.[33] Nevertheless, the IOC held to the traditional
rules regarding amateurism until the '90s.[129]

The Cold War created tensions amongst countries allied to the two superpowers.
The strained relationship between East and West Germany created a difficult
political situation for the IOC. Because of its role in World War II, Germany
was not allowed to compete at the 1948 Winter Olympics.[24] In 1950 the IOC
recognised the West German Olympic Committee, and invited East and West
Germany to compete as a unified team at the 1952 Winter Games.[130] East
Germany declined the invitation and instead sought international legitimacy
separate from West Germany.[131] In 1955 the Soviet Union recognised East
Germany as a sovereign state, thereby giving more credibility to East
Germany's campaign to become an independent participant at the Olympics. The
IOC agreed to provisionally accept the East German National Olympic Committee
with the condition that East and West Germans compete on one team.[132] The
situation became tenuous when the [Berlin Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin
Wall") was constructed in 1962 and western nations began refusing visas to
East German athletes.[133] The uneasy compromise of a unified team held until
the 1968 Grenoble Games when the IOC officially split the teams and threatened
to reject the host-city bids of any country that refused entry visas to East
German athletes.[134]

### Boycott

The Winter Games have had only one national team [boycott](/wiki/Boycott
"Boycott") when [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") decided not to participate in
the 1980 Winter Olympics held in Lake Placid. Prior to the Games the IOC
agreed to allow China to compete in the Olympics for the first time since
1952. China was given permission to compete as the "People's Republic of
China" (PRC) and to use the PRC flag and anthem. Until 1980 the island of
Taiwan had been competing under the name "Republic of China" (ROC) and had
been using the ROC flag and anthem.[50] The IOC attempted to have the
countries compete together but when this proved to be unacceptable the IOC
demanded that Taiwan cease to call itself the "Republic of China".[135][136]
The IOC renamed the island "[Chinese Taipei](/wiki/Chinese_Taipei "Chinese
Taipei")" and demanded that it adopt a different flag and national anthem,
stipulations that Taiwan would not agree to. Despite numerous appeals and
court hearings the IOC's decision stood. When the Taiwanese athletes arrived
at the Olympic village with their Republic of China identification cards they
were not admitted. They subsequently left the Olympics in protest, just before
the opening ceremonies.[50] Taiwan returned to Olympic competition at the 1984
Winter Games in Sarajevo as Chinese Taipei. The country agreed to compete
under a flag bearing the emblem of their National Olympic Committee and to
play the anthem of their National Olympic Committee should one of their
athletes win a gold medal. The agreement remains in place to this day.[137]

## Sports

The [Olympic Charter](/wiki/Olympic_Charter "Olympic Charter") limits [winter
sports](/wiki/Winter_sports "Winter sports") to "those ... which are practised
on snow or ice."[138] Since 1992 a number of new sports have been added to the
Olympic programme; which include short track speed skating, snowboarding,
freestyle and moguls skiing. The addition of these events has broadened the
appeal of the Winter Olympics beyond Europe and North America. While European
powers such as Norway and Germany still dominate the traditional Winter
Olympic sports, countries such as South Korea, Australia and Canada are
finding success in the new sports. The results are: more parity in the
national medal tables; more interest in the Winter Olympics; and higher global
television ratings.[139]

### Demonstration events

[Demonstration sports](/wiki/Demonstration_sports#Winter_Olympics
"Demonstration sports") have historically provided a venue for host countries
to attract publicity to locally popular sports by having a competition without
granting medals. Demonstration sports were discontinued after
[1992](/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics "1992 Winter Olympics").[155] Military
patrol, a precursor to the [biathlon](/wiki/Biathlon "Biathlon"), was a medal
sport in 1924 and was demonstrated in 1928, 1936 and 1948, becoming an
official sport in 1960.[156] The [special figures](/wiki/Special_figures
"Special figures") figure skating event was only contested at the [1908 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_1908_Summer_Olympics "Figure skating at
the 1908 Summer Olympics").[157] [Bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy") (Russian hockey)
is a sport popular in the Nordic countries and Russia. In the latter it's
considered a [national sport](/wiki/National_sport "National sport").[158] It
was demonstrated at the Oslo Games.[159] [Ice stock
sport](/wiki/Ice_stock_sport "Ice stock sport"), a German variant of curling,
was demonstrated in 1936 in Germany and 1964 in Austria.[20] The [ski
ballet](/wiki/Ski_ballet "Ski ballet") event, later known as ski-acro, was
demonstrated in 1988 and 1992.[160] [Skijöring](/wiki/Skij%C3%B6ring
"Skijöring"), skiing behind dogs, was a demonstration sport in St. Moritz in
1928.[159] A [sled-dog race](/wiki/Sled_dog_race_at_the_1932_Winter_Olympics
"Sled dog race at the 1932 Winter Olympics") was held at Lake Placid in
1932.[159] [Speed skiing](/wiki/Speed_skiing "Speed skiing") was demonstrated
in Albertville at the 1992 Winter Olympics.[161] [Winter
pentathlon](/wiki/Winter_pentathlon "Winter pentathlon"), a variant of the
[modern pentathlon](/wiki/Modern_pentathlon "Modern pentathlon"), was included
as a demonstration event at the 1948 Games in Switzerland. It included [cross-
country skiing](/wiki/Cross-country_skiing "Cross-country skiing"),
[shooting](/wiki/Shooting "Shooting"), [downhill
skiing](/wiki/Downhill_\(ski_competition\) "Downhill \(ski competition\)"),
[fencing](/wiki/Fencing_\(sport\) "Fencing \(sport\)") and [horse
riding](/wiki/Equestrian_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Equestrian at the Summer
Olympics").[141]

Unlike the Summer Olympics, the cancelled [1940 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1940_Winter_Olympics "1940 Winter Olympics") and [1944 Winter
Olympics](/wiki/1944_Winter_Olympics "1944 Winter Olympics") are _not_
included in the official Roman numeral counts for the Winter Games. While the
official titles of the Summer Games count [Olympiads](/wiki/Olympiad
"Olympiad"), the titles of the Winter Games only count the Games themselves.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Winter_olympics_all_cities.PNG/630px-
Winter_olympics_all_cities.PNG)](/wiki/File:Winter_olympics_all_cities.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Winter_olympics_all_cities.PNG "Enlarge")

Map of Winter Olympics locations. Countries that have hosted one Winter
Olympics are shaded green, while countries that have hosted two or more are
shaded blue.

## Notes

  1. **Jump up ^** "French and English are the official languages for the Olympic Games.", [[1]](http://www.olympic.org/fr/).(..)
  2. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ _**c**_ The official website of the Olympic Movement now treats Men's Military Patrol at the 1924 Games as an event within the sport of [Biathlon](/wiki/Biathlon "Biathlon").[1][2] However, the 1924 Official Report treats it as an event and discipline within what was then called Skiing and is now called [Nordic Skiing](/wiki/Nordic_Skiing "Nordic Skiing").[3][4]
  3. **Jump up ^** At the closing of the 1924 Games a prize was also awarded for 'alpinisme' ([mountaineering](/wiki/Mountaineering "Mountaineering")), a sport that did not lend itself very well for tournaments: [Pierre de Coubertin](/wiki/Pierre_de_Coubertin "Pierre de Coubertin") presented a prize for 'alpinisme' to [Charles Granville Bruce](/wiki/Charles_Granville_Bruce "Charles Granville Bruce"), the leader of the expedition that tried to climb [Mount Everest](/wiki/Mount_Everest "Mount Everest") in 1922.
  4. **Jump up ^** The US beat the Soviets as part of a [medal round](/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_1980_Winter_Olympics#Final_round "Ice hockey at the 1980 Winter Olympics") that also included [Finland](/wiki/Finland_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Finland men's national ice hockey team") and [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team "Sweden men's national ice hockey team"), so they did not actually win the gold medal until beating Finland a few days later.[54][55]
